display_title.display_title:
Zaïre – Projet de développement
            des palmiers à huile : Zaïre - Projet palmiers à huile

subtopic: Crops and Crop Management Systems,Environmental Economics & Policies,Economic Theory & Research,National Governance,Banks & Banking Reform
teratopic: Finance and Financial Sector Development,Environment,Governance,Agriculture,Macroeconomics and Economic Growth

abstracts.cdata!:
This report is the Project Completion
            Report (PCR) for the Oil-Palm Development Project in Zaire.
            The Credit was closed on December 31, 1987, four years
            behind schedule. It was not fully disbursed. Parts I and III
            were submitted for comment to the Borrower on July 20, 1990.
            No comments were received. Palm oil production on mostly
            foreign owned commercial plantations in Zaire had declined
            steadily since independence from 240,000 tons of oil per
            annum in 1959 to about 125,000 tons of oil in 1976. The main
            reasons were the turbulent period after independence in 1960
            and the successive measures of Zairianization and
            demonetization. The decision of the Zaire Government to
            return the plantations to private management in the late
            seventies did provide an opportunity for the Bank to help
            reverse the long decline in a sector in which it was
            believed that Zaire had a clear comparative advantage and a
            natural potential to rehabilitate an important
            agro-industry. Project execution ran into many difficulties.
            It became effective only 4 years after approval, and the
            project closing date also had to be extended by almost four
            years, until December 31, 1987. The last disbursement was
            made on October 20, 1988, about ten years after project
            approval. Despite these difficulties, the project achieved
            its technical goals by completing its planting and factory
            rehabilitation program, most of its labor housing
            construction program, and improving the oil palm seed-supply
            situation in Zaire.
